title: Kingham, in the Cotswolds, is Filled to the Brim With British Country Charm
text:
Designated an area of outstanding natural beauty, the largest in England, the Cotswolds represents the English rural idyll at its picture-postcard best: thatched, honey-stone cottages wreathed with purple wisteria, centuries-old gastro-pubs, babbling brooks and undulating green hills, stately homes, horse races and cheese-rolling competitions.



And perhaps the most in-demand village of all is Kingham, which Luke Morgan, director of Strutt & Parker’s country department, described as the “Notting Hill of the Cotswolds,” referencing the chic, high-end and celebrity-filled London neighborhood.



It’s a “lovely village,” he said of Kingham. “You’ve got loads of people with loads of money who want to be near its smart pubs and its high-end shops. And, honestly, a lot of people who have a lot of money come here to stargaze,” he said. Celebrities that live and visit the town include politicians, royalty and entertainment stars.

More: More House Hunters Buoy Prime London Prices

Each town and village in the Cotswolds area has its own identity and draw, but what the whole area offers is "a getaway destination for an improved quality of life," said Rupert Wakely, partner and office head for Knight Frank’s branch in nearby Stow on the Wold.



Kingham specifically, he said, is their A-list village, “where people want to be. You’ve got Daylesford Organic Farm Shop up the road about a mile away. You have The Wild Rabbit, which is a restaurant that’s become very trendy, and the Kingham Plough, which is a very good pub in the village. And you have a train that takes you to London Paddington station, which is the main draw to the town. All those things marry together to become extremely popular for weekend homes for Londoners and primary residencies,” he said.



Boundaries



Kingham is surrounded by countryside, with the village of Churchill to its east, the Daylesford estate to its northwest, and Bledington to the southwest and Oddington to the northwest.

More: Historic English House With Period Features Asks £1.15 Million

Price Range

Both primary- and second-home buyers pay a premium to live anywhere in the Cotswolds, according to data from Savills. Its research found the average sale price in the 12 months to April 2019 in the Cotswolds to be £469,456 (US$574,792) compared to the England and Wales average of £289,296.



These prices have risen by 23.5% in the past five years— in terms of properties that have actually been sold by Savills—and 1.2% in the past 12 months, compared to just 15.9%, and 0.7% respectively for England and Wales.



“There is a real premium for living within a national park or area of natural beauty,” said Frances Clacy, a research analyst at Savills. “Housing supply remains constrained, and the integrity of the built environment is well preserved. As a result, homes within and immediately surrounding the parks are very often highly sought-after heritage buildings, for which buyers are prepared to pay a significant premium.”



“Today the Cotswolds is becoming quite regionalized,” Mr. Morgan said. “Everyone wants to be on the eastern boundary near Daylesford, Soho Farmhouse and the M40—which is pushing prices up” in Kingham and the surrounding areas.

More: 11-Bedroom Flat Facing London’s Posh Park Lane Relists, Asking £20M

In Kingham, specifically, often properties trade hands for several million pounds. “Kingham’s up there with the highest-priced villages in Cotswolds,” Mr. Morgan said.



Helen Whitfield, director of Strutt & Parker’s Moreton-in-Marsh branch, agreed, pointing out that square foot values in the Cotswolds challenge some top London postcodes.



Kingham has an average price of £897,295, she said.



A Grade II Listed Cotswold house set on the edge of Kingham village is asking for £1.65 million. Knight Frank

More: A Kensington Home With a Sense of Style

Housing Stock



A large proportion of the area’s architecture—from imposing stately homes to traditional thatched cottages—are constructed from the golden, locally mined Oolitic limestone, known as Cotswold Stone. Strutt & Parker sells all types of property in the Cotswolds, from chocolate box cottages and traditional townhouses to rural retreats, farms and country estates.



Mr. Wakely said classic Georgian stone manor houses that have been renovated, usually set in a prime village position, are still the No. 1 on buyers’ wish lists, "especially for those leaving the London rat race looking for their Cotswolds country idyll.”



What Makes it Unique



Kingham is “surely the ultimate super village,” Mr. Morgan said. “Its foodie credentials means very rarely do properties even come on the open market; people never want to leave. When we do have have something for sale there, it flies off the shelf.” And people pay a premium to live there, he said. “They want to hang out with celebrities, they want to be in the town that’s often named England’s favorite village.”



Kingham has access to green beauty and the country and it offers easy access to busy cities, including London, making it a popular place to relocate. Direct trains from Kingham take you to London Paddington station in one hour and 25 minutes.

More: Central London Chapel Available to Convert Into Luxury Home

“Access to London is key for most of the Cotswolds,” Mr. Wakely said. “When many families make their eventual big move out of London, the Cotswolds provides the perfect setting to be able to keep in touch with London three days or so a week. The schooling, both private and state, is also a pulling factor."



Interior view of a five-bedroom Cotswolds house currently listed for sale. Knight Frank

Luxury Amenities



Daylesford, one of the area’s most famous attractions, is an estate on the edge of Oxfordshire, right outside of Kingham.The Wild Rabbit is a fine-dining restaurant and modern British inn serving seasonal organic produce as part of the estate.



Other notable place to dine include the Kingham Plough, a very posh pub with hotel rooms attached that often makes lists of England’s best gastropubs.



About 12 miles from Kingham is Soho Farmhouse, the hotel, members club and spa, and part of the famed Soho House chain. It arrived in 2015, attracting hordes of A-listers.



Shops in the village include Westcote Design, a maker of bespoke furniture that’s been in business for a quarter of a century; and Tiles of Stow, a family-owned business that has been selling hand-made tiles since 1988.



Rupert Sturgis a partner and office head at Knight Frank Cirencester, said aside from the two public houses, The Kingham Plough and The Wild Rabbit and Daylesford Organic, Kingham has a village shop and post office, a play park and footfields.

From Penta: A Lamborghini Veneno Could Fetch US$6.3 Million at Bonhams

Those who seek day-to-day amenities go to Chipping Norton, Stow-on-the-Wold and Burford, which are just a few miles from Kingham. There’s a wider selection of offerings at Cheltenham and Oxford, which are about 25 miles away, a drive that takes about 50 minutes..



In Stow-on-the-Wold, The LBD Boutique, which opened in 2007, offers curated collections of “the little black dress” and other women’s apparel from niche designers, and the Cotswold Sweet Company is a purveyor of handmade chocolates, fudge and other sweet treats.



Antiques in the Cotswolds are a main attraction for shoppers. Some four miles from Kingham, in neighboring Chipping Norton, Station Mill Antiques Centre, established in 1997, has 80 dealers who offer everything from furnishings to knickknacks. Chipping Norton also is the home of The Quiet Woman Antiques Center, which has a selection of Georgian, Edwardian and Victorian furniture as well as collectibles. Tara Antiques Centre, which is 4.4 miles away in Stow-on-the-Wold, has 30 dealers who sell everything from vintage items present-day objects.

More: Amid Political Changes, Buyers Would Be Wise to Consider Prime Central London

Kingham has a community primary school in the village, as well as the independent co-educational Kingham Hill School for students ages 11 through 18. Also close by are Great Tew Primary, a state-funded elementary school, and Windrush Valley School, named one of the top 50 prep schools in England.



The surrounding countryside offers a large number of sporting activities, too, including shooting, hunting, fishing, riding, water sports as well as long hikes. The Cotswolds Way, in particular, is a 102-mile walking trail, running the length of the area, from the market town of Chipping Campden in the north to the World Heritage city of Bath in the south, passing through villages and historic sites, including the Neolithic burial chamber at Belas Knap, Sudeley Castle and Hailes Abbey. There are also stately homes to visit, including Blenheim Palace and Chavenage House.



Knight Frank

Who Lives There



A real mix of Brits and internationals, older retired couples, and young families call Kingham home. “Despite the seemingly rural location, we see lots of parents do a three-day commute to London, and from some parts, it is even possible to do a commute daily,” Mr. Morgan said.



Sophie Salter, associate partner at Cotswolds Property specialist Butler Sherborn, said she sells to all sorts of people, but increasingly she has noticed more grandparents moving to the Cotswolds to downsize and be close to their children to help with childcare.

More: In England, Real Estate Transaction Values in the South Trump Those in the North

Notable Residents



Musician Alex James, from the U.K. band Blur, lives on a farm in Kingham where he now makes cheese, according to published reports.



Author Fiona Mountain, who was formerly a BBC Radio press officer, and is now the author of historical mysteries lives in the town, too, according to The Independent.



Outlook



“The market moves in ebbs and flows, but there has been an increase in international interest in the Cotswolds, with many having to buy off-market because there’s very little around publicly,” Mr. Morgan said.



The weak pound, he said, is making the area particularly attractive for those coming from outside England. “I expect this to continue with expat buyers currently in Hong Kong looking increasingly likely to return to the U.K. earlier than expected,” he said.

According to figures from the Land Registry, Savills said that the average price of the homes sold across the area encompassing Kingham, Rollright and Enstone for the 12-month period from June 2018 to June 2019 was £585,266. This is 28.6% higher than the average in the previous 12-month period, due to the mix of homes sold, and 27.1% up from five years ago.



Oliver Knight, an associate on the residential research team at Knight Frank, said that the Cotswolds market has remained steady compared with the rest of the country. He pointed out that the transaction rate over the last year in West Oxfordshire, where Kingham is located, was 4% higher, whereas the rate in all of England has fallen 5.1% during the same time period.



But, he said that first-quarter comparison prices from 2018 to 2019 show a 1.4% decrease in Kingham and the surrounding area.



Mr. Wakely said despite volatility in the U.K. as a result of uncertainty with Brexit, things look bright: “When the market goes up and down, the Cotswolds tends to hold firm on the prices due to its desirability. There is plenty of demand for Cotswold homes, and that is only going to continue.”
